questions.text: As per Sade classification, what is the grade assigned to atelectasis of the middle ear?
questions.solution:
The term atelectasis is used to define the tympanic membrane touching the promontory. This is classified as grade 3 by Sade classification.

  • Pars Tensa retraction is graded using Sade grading
  • Pars flaccida retraction is graded using Tos grading

Sade’s classification of retraction of pars tensa:

  • Grade 1 – Mild retraction not touching the long process of the incus 
  • Grade 2 – Retracted drum touching the long process of the incus
  • Grade 3 – Touching promontory but mobile on segalization—atelectasis of the middle ear
  • Grade 4 – Plastered to promontory (immobile)—adhesive middle ear

Tos’ classification of retraction of pars flaccida:

  • Grade 1 – Mild attic retraction not touching the neck of the malleus.
  • Grade 2 – Touching neck of the malleus
  • Grade 3 – Limited outer attic wall erosion
  • Grade 4 – Severe outer attic wall erosion

questions.text: Which of the following is not a clinical feature of Keratosis obturans?
questions.solution:
Otorrhoea is not a clinical feature of keratosis obturans.

Keratosis obturans is the accumulation of a large plug of desquamated keratin in the external auditory meatus. Primary auditory canal cholesteatoma is the invasion of squamous tissue from the ear into a localized area of bone erosion.

Otorrhoea is a clinical feature of primary auditory canal cholesteatoma. Primary auditory canal cholesteatoma is the closest differential diagnosis of keratosis obturans.

The following table differentiates the clinical features of keratosis obturans and primary auditory canal cholesteatoma.

Keratosis obturans Primary auditory canal cholesteatoma

●      Severe otalgia

●      Conductive hearing loss

●      Thickened tympanic membrane

●      Keratin plug occluding the canal

●      Widened ear canal

●      Hyperemia of canal skin, sometimes with granulations

●      Otorrhoea

●      Normal hearing

●      Tympanic membrane normal

●      Keratin in a random pattern

●      Localized osteitis/erosion of ear canal (usually posteroinferior)

●      Sequestration of bone

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard of ear reconstruction in microtia?

choices.text: Conchal cartilage from the normal ear

questions.solution: The gold standard of ear reconstruction in microtia is an ear of carved autogenous costal cartilage.

questions.text: What is the embryological origin of the eustachian tube?
questions.solution:
The eustachian tube develops from the proximal part of the first pharyngeal pouch.

Related Pearl: Embryology of the ear

Structures of the ear Embryological origin
Auricle or pinna 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arch
External auditory meatus 1st pharyngeal arch
Tympanic membrane All 3 germ layers
Malleus and incus 1st pharyngeal arch
Stapes suprastructure 2nd pharyngeal arch
Stapes footplate and annular ligament Otic capsule
Tympanic cavity 1st pharyngeal pouch
Eustachian tube 1st pharyngeal pouch
Membranous labyrinth Otic vesicle
Semicircular canals and utricle Pars superior
Saccule and cochlea Pars inferior

questions.text: Which of the following structures pass through the posterior canaliculus of the middle ear?
questions.solution:
The chorda tympani passes through the posterior canaliculus of the middle ear.

The chorda tympani branches off from the facial nerve and enters the middle ear cavity through the posterior canaliculus which is situated in the angle between the posterior and lateral walls of the middle ear. It then runs through the substance of the tympanic membrane and leaves the tympanic cavity through the anterior canaliculus. The nerve enters the infratemporal fossa by passing through the petrotympanic fissure.

questions.text: Which of the following is medial to the pyramidal eminence of the middle ear?
questions.solution:
Sinus tympani is medial to the pyramidal eminence of the middle ear.

The pyramidal eminence is situated in the posterior wall of the middle ear in front of the vertical part of the facial nerve canal. It is hollow and contains the stapedius muscle. Its summit is pierced by the tendon of stapedius.

It divides the posterior space into a medial sinus tympani and a lateral facial recess. It is a landmark for the second genu of the facial nerve and houses the vertical segment of the facial nerve & the nerve to stapedius. The aditus (opening to the mastoid) lies just above it.

questions.text: Which of the following contains perilymph?
questions.solution:
The cochlear aqueduct contains the perilymph.

Scala tympani is connected with the subarachnoid space through the aqueduct of cochlea. It Carries perilymph.

The cochlear duct, vestibular aqueduct and endolymphatic sac have endolymph.

questions.text: What is the lining of the marked part of the eustachian tube?
questions.solution:
The marked part is the bony eustachian tube. It is lined by ciliated columnar epithelium.

The mucosal lining of the middle ear is continuous with that of nasopharynx but shows variations:

  • Bony eustachian tube: ciliated columnar
  • Cartilaginous eustachian tube: ciliated pseudostratified columnar
  • Protympanum: ciliated columnar
  • Most of the middle ear space: cuboidal
  • Epitympanum & mastoid air cells: flat non-ciliated

questions.text: Which of the following is the scaphoid fossa in the given image?
questions.solution:
The area marked by B is the scaphoid fossa of the pinna.

The following image shows different parts of the pinna:

questions.text: What type of tympanogram is expected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image is diagnostic of serous otitis media, and type B tympanogram is seen with this condition.

Following features in the given image favours the diagnosis of serous otitis media.

  • The golden yellow colour of the tympanic membrane (due to clear watery straw-coloured effusion filling the middle ear)
  • Structures of the middle ear are seen clearly (due to the clear fluid in the middle ear cavity)
  • Thin leash of blood vessels are seen along the handle of the malleus and the periphery of the tympanic membrane (this differentiates the condition from ASOM where there is marked congestion of the tympanic membrane)

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A person travelling on flight experiences blockade sensation in his right ear, which then progressed to sharp pain during descent. Which of the following measures will prevent the occurrence of a similar episode in his next air travel?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms are suggestive of the middle ear barotrauma during flight descent. Using vasoconstrictor (oxymetazoline) nasal spray half an hour before descent can prevent this.

Otitic barotrauma is a non-suppurative condition resulting from the failure of the eustachian tube to maintain middle ear pressure at ambient atmospheric level. The usual cause is rapid descent during an air flight, underwater diving or compression in the pressure chamber.

Measures to prevent middle ear barotrauma:

  • Swallow repeatedly during descent (as swallowing opens up the eustachian tube and equalizes the middle ear pressure)
  • Avoid sleeping during descent as the number of swallows normally decrease during sleep
  • Auto inflation of the tube by Valsalva should be performed intermittently
  • Vasoconstrictor nasal spray/ antihistaminic and systemic decongestant tablet  half an hour before descent can effectively prevent this
  • Occlusive earplugs are contraindicated due to the risk of the external ear barotrauma

questions.text: As per Austin’s classification of Ossicular defects, Loss of malleus and incus with the presence of stapes suprastructure is classified as __________
questions.solution:
Loss of malleus and incus with the presence of stapes suprastructure is classified as type C as per Austin’s classification of ossicular defects.

Related Pearl: Austin's classification

Based on the presence or absence of malleus handle (M) and stapes suprastructure (S) assuming incus is absent in all cases.

Type

Malleus handle

Stapes superstructure

Reconstruction

A

M +

S +

PORP

B

M +

S -

TORP

C

M -

S +

PORP

D

M -

S -

TORP

PORP: Partial Ossicular Reconstruction Prosthesis; TORP: Total Ossicular Reconstruction Prosthesis

questions.text: Which of the following is called Schwartze operation?
questions.solution:
Cortical mastoidectomy is called Schwartze operation.

Cortical mastoidectomy, also known as simple mastoidectomy or Schwartze operation involves an exenteration of all accessible mastoid air cells preserving the posterior meatal wall.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with complaints of scanty foul-smelling discharge from the right ear. The following is her otoscopic finding. What will be your main modality of management?
questions.solution:
The child has a history of scanty foul-smelling otorrhoea and the otoscopic picture shows an attic cholesteatoma. This favors the diagnosis of an atticoantral (unsafe) type of chronic otitis media. A surgical procedure like tympanomastoid exploration would be the main modality in managing this child.

Surgery is the only treatment for cholesteatoma. The procedure of choice is modified radical mastoidectomy (MRM), a type of canal wall-down tympanomastoidectomy.

Cholesteatomas are keratinized squamous epithelium masses present in the middle ear cavity. They are described as skin in the wrong place. Although it is called cholesteatoma, this term is a misnomer as it is not a tumor and is not composed of cholesterol crystals.

Cholesteatomas can be classified into the following types :

  • Primary acquired cholesteatomas occur in the absence of previous infection or perforation and patients present with hearing loss.
  • Secondary acquired cholesteatomas occur in those who have a preexisting perforation. 
  • Congenital cholesteatomas arise from the embryonic epidermal cells present in the middle ear cleft. It can be visualized as a white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane. 

Clinical features of cholesteatomas include hearing loss (due to perforation of the tympanic membrane and middle ear bone destruction) and otorrhea. Cholesteatomas have a high potential to destroy the bone due to invasion and enzymatic bone destruction. 

Diagnosis of cholesteatoma can be done by history, examination, and radiography. CT can demonstrate bony defects such as ossicular erosion, mastoid aditus widening, and bony ear canal erosion.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman complains of progressive hearing loss, which aggravated during pregnancy. Pure tone audiometry reveals a Carhart's notch and she is diagnosed with otosclerosis. Identify the procedure done for this patient's condition.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a stapedotomy procedure performed in the middle ear.

It can be identified as a stapedotomy procedure by the following features in the image given:

  • The footplate of the stapes is not removed
  • The prosthesis is placed by creating a hole in the footplate of the stapes

Stapedotomy is the excision of the superstructure of stapes and drilling a hole in the footplate & placing a piston in the hole. It is done to bypass the immobile stapes using a piston which will take over the function of conducting sound.

Contraindications for Stapedotomy:

  • Only hearing ear
  • Positive Schwartze sign
  • Otitis externa
  • Meniere’s disease: can damage the inner ear while drilling a hole in the footplate
  • Young children
  • Professional athletes, pilots, construction workers, and divers: Sudden changes in pressure can displace the piston and cause vertigo.
  • Those who work in noisy surroundings: Surgery makes them more vulnerable to noise-induced hearing loss.

Otosclerosis is a primary disease of the bony labyrinth where foci of irregularly placed spongy bone replace part of the normally dense enchondral layer of the bony otic capsule. It is more commonly seen in females between 20-30 years of age and the hearing loss is aggravated during pregnancy and menopause.

Clinically, patients present with painless progressive bilateral conductive hearing loss and paracusis willisii (patient hears better in noisy surroundings as other people raise their voices to be heard). 

Tuning fork tests and audiometry will reveal the presence of conductive hearing loss. The bone conduction curve may show a dip, which is maximum at 2000Hz, known as Carhart’s notch.

The image shown below shows Carhart's notch.

Other options:

Options B and C: Stapes mobilization and Lempert’s fenestration operation are older procedures seldom performed these days.

Option D: Stapedectomy involves complete removal of the anterior and posterior portions of the footplate, leaving the membrane below the footplate intact. Now the oval window with its overlying membrane is covered with a piece of fascia and the prosthesis is placed over this.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Carhart's notch?

choices.text: Typically dips at 4000 Hz in air conduction
Typically dips at 4000 Hz in bone conduction
Typically dips at 2000 Hz in air conduction
Typically dips at 2000 Hz in bone conduction

questions.solution:
Carhart's notch typically dips at 2000 Hz in Bone Conduction.

Pure Tone Audiometry in Otosclerosis:

  • Air conduction is poor & worse for lower frequencies.
  • Large A-B gap
  • Bone conduction is normal.
  • In some cases, there is a dip in the bone conduction curve.
  • It is different at different frequencies but maximum at 2000 Hz and is called Carhart’s notch.
  • Note: Boiler’s notch is a similar dip in BC and AC curve but at 4000 Hz seen in noise-induced hearing loss.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is diagnosed to have Meniere's disease. He says he constantly gets vertiginous episodes when exposed to loud sounds. Which of the following term can be used to describe this symptom?
questions.solution:
Tullio phenomenon describes the vertiginous episodes associated with exposure to loud noise in a patient with Meniere's disease. This phenomenon is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis (drop attacks) is when a patient with Meniere’s develops sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness. It is an uncommon manifestation. Pathogenesis not well understood.

Lermoyez syndrome - Here symptoms of Meniere's disease are seen in reverse order. Initially, there is a progressive deterioration of hearing, followed by an attack of vertigo.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient has hearing difficulty in his right ear, with frequent episodes of tinnitus. Further clinical examination shows a sensorineural type of hearing loss. Given below is his brain MRI image. Which of the following is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and MRI image are diagnostic of acoustic neuroma. The rollover phenomenon is seen in this condition.

When speech audiometry is done on this patient, it shows poor speech discrimination. A reduction in discrimination score when loudness is increased beyond a particular limit is called the rollover phenomenon. It is seen in retrocochlear type of hearing loss, as with an acoustic neuroma.

Vestibular schwannoma or ‘acoustic neuroma’ are benign tumors that exhibit Schwann cell differentiation and arise from the vestibular division of the VIII nerve but rarely may arise from the cochlear division of the VIII nerve within the internal auditory canal.

  • Mostly seen in 40- 60 years and no sexual predilection.
  • Progressive unilateral hearing loss with tinnitus is the most common presenting symptom.
  • Vth cranial nerve is the earliest cranial nerve to be involved.
  • Other nerves involved are IX, X, and XI cranial nerves and may also cause displacement of the brainstem resulting in increased intracranial pressure.

MRI with Gadolinium contrast is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acoustic neuroma. The mass will be seen extending into the intracanalicular portion of the internal acoustic meatus. Extracanalicular extension into the cerebellopontine angle along the path of least resistance can lead to an "ice-cream-cone" appearance.

Other options:

The recruitment phenomenon refers to abnormal growth of loud sounds (sound is amplified in order to be heard better). A loud sound that is tolerable by a normal ear may grow to abnormal levels of loudness in the recruiting ear and thus becomes intolerable. It is a feature of cochlear pathologies like Meniere's disease and presbycusis. 

Diplacusis is the discordance of sounds in which a single auditory stimulus of a particular frequency is heard at different pitches in both ears.

Tullio phenomenon is a condition where loud sounds produce vertigo due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

The recruitment phenomenon, diplacusis, and Tullio phenomenon are all seen in Meniere's disease.

Related Pearl: Speech audiometry

Consists of two components:

  • Speech reception threshold: The minimum intensity at which 50% of the words are repeated correctly by the patient.
  • Speech discrimination score: The patient’s ability to understand speech.
    • Percentage of phonetically balanced words delivered 30dB above SRT which are identified correctly.
    • In normal persons and those with conductive hearing loss, a high score of 90–100% can be obtained.
    • It is reduced in cochlear lesions, very poor and out of proportion to hearing loss in retrocochlear hearing loss, and worst in cortical deafness.

Roll-over phenomenon:

  • Feature of retrocochlear hearing loss.
  • When speech intensity is increased above a particular level, SDS falls instead of maintaining a plateau as in cochlear deafness.

Uses:

  • To differentiate organic from non-organic hearing loss.
  • To differentiate cochlear from retrocochlear lesions.
  • To find the intensity at which discrimination score is the best which is useful for fitting a hearing aid.

Related Pearl: The differences between cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss

Test
Cochlear hearing loss
Retrocochlear hearing loss
Recruitment (ABLB test)
Present
Absent
*SISI score (Short Increment Sensitivity Index)
70 – 100%
0 – 20% 
Acoustic reflex threshold
Decreased due to recruitment
Increased
**Tone decay (nerve fatigue)
Absent
Present
Acoustic reflex decay (nerve fatigue)
Absent
Present
OAEs
Absent
Present
BERA (Best test)
Delayed wave-I, rest are normal
Only wave-I is present, rest are absent or affected
Speech discrimination score
  • Reduced
  • Roll over phenomenon absent
  • Very poor
  • Roll over phenomenon present

*Short Increment Sensitivity Index: A normal ear can’t differentiate short increments of sound but a recruiting ear can. SISI test is started sound 20db above the hearing threshold of the patient and 20 increments of 1db are given every 5 seconds. The total number of increments heard by the patient is recorded. SISI score of 70-100% is seen in cochlear deafness and of 0-20% in retrocochlear deafness.

** Threshold tone decay: It is a function of nerve fatigue. A Tone of 4000Hz is presented at 5dB above the patient’s threshold of hearing for 60 seconds. A normal ear can hear continuously for a minute but a patient with abnormal hearing stops hearing before 1 minute. Loudness is increased until the patient can hear the sound. If loudness has to be increased by more than 30dB, it indicates retrocochlear hearing loss.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the medical management of Meniere's disease, acts by causing dilatation of the labyrinthine blood vessels?
questions.solution:
Betahistine (vertin), used in the medical management of Meniere's disease acts by causing dilatation of the labyrinthine blood vessels, thereby improving the microvascular circulation in the stria vascularis of the cochlea. It is also found to inhibit the vestibular nuclei activity.

Other drugs used in the medical management of Meniere's disease are

  • Prochlorperazine (stemetil), is a vestibular sedative.
  • Diuretics such as furosemide and hydrochlorothiazide are used to control recurrent attacks.
  • Propantheline bromide (probanthine), an anticholinergic agent is also found to be effective.

questions.text: What is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image shows a dark-colored summit over a swelling, usually seen in a sebaceous cyst.

Sebaceous cysts are the retention cysts of the sebaceous gland that are usually present on the face, scalp, or scrotum. They contain yellowish-white cheesy material with fat and epithelium.

Clinical features: 

  • The swelling is painless, soft, and freely mobile.
  • Though non-transilluminating, they are Paget's test positive (fluctuant).
  • Punctum is seen in 70% of the patients with sebaceous cysts. They are dark in color due to the accumulation of denuded epithelium.
  • They also have an unpleasant sebum odor.
  • The swelling can ulcerate and become painful (Cock’s peculiar tumor).
  • Some cysts over the scalp may also harden over time (Sebaceous horn).
  • Many may get infected and lead to abscess formation.

Treatment:

Excision including skin adjacent to punctum using elliptical incision-dissection method.
Incision and avulsion of cyst wall.
In the presence of an abscess, an initial treatment with an incision later followed by excision of the cyst

Other options:

Option A: Dermoid cysts present as firm painless subcutaneous nodules and are of 4 types:

  • Sequestration dermoid - sequestration of epithelium during embryological development
  • Tubulodermoid - accumulation of secretions from ectodermal tube/duct
  • Implantation dermoid - implantation of the epidermis due to trauma
  • Teratomatous dermoid - having all 3 germ layers (ecto, meso, and endoderm)

Option C: Common causes of perichondritis include trauma either iatrogenic (surgical incision) or noniatrogenic (laceration, hematoma). It can also be due to the extension of infection from diffuse otitis externa or furuncle of the meatus. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an organism commonly implicated. Initially, the pinna is red, hot, painful, and stiff. In the later stages, an abscess may form between the cartilage and perichondrium with necrosis of cartilage as the cartilage survives only on the blood supply from its perichondrium. The image below shows a patient with perichondritis

Option D: Skin tags are benign outgrowths that appear from the skin and consists of a fibrovascular core alongwith fat and other epidermal elements. The image below depicts the same.

questions.text: Following is the otoscopic image of a surfer complaining of deafness. Pure tone audiometry is suggestive of conductive hearing loss. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The otoscopic finding is suggestive of exostoses.

A surfer with a clinical diagnosis of a conductive type of hearing loss with the otoscopic image showing multiple, sessile bumpy swellings in the external auditory canal draws us to a diagnosis of exostoses.

Exostoses are bilateral multiple smooth sessile bony swellings in the deeper canal seen in surfers. It is also called as surfer’s ear. They can be removed with a high-speed drill to restore the normal external auditory canal.

The following CT image shows the difference between a normal ear canal and an ear canal with exostoses.

The following table differentiates osteoma and exostoses

Osteoma

Exostoses/surfer's Ear

Single

Multiple

Unilateral

Bilateral

Pedunculated, hard

Sessile, smooth

Outer canal

Inner, deeper canal

arises from cancellous bone

arises from compact bone

Ceruminoma: It is a tumour of modified sweat glands. It presents as a smooth, firm, skin-covered polypoid swelling in the outer part of the meatus. Wide surgical excision is done. 

Sebaceous adenoma: It arises from sebaceous glands of the meatus and presents as smooth, skin-covered swelling in the outer meatus. Treatment is surgical excision.

questions.text: Which of the following treatment modalities has no role in managing an acoustic neuroma?
questions.solution:
External beam radiotherapy has no role in the treatment of acoustic neuromas due to low tolerance of the central nervous system to radiation.

Treatment options for acoustic neuroma:

  • Surgery is the mainstay of treatment of acoustic neuromas 
  • Stereotactic radiosurgery is an alternative for people who refuse/can not tolerate surgery. Here, beams are modified and focused only to concentrate on the tumour and have little effect on the surrounding tissue. 
    • Can be done by:
      • X-knife using LINAC
      • Gamma-knife using Cobalt 60
      • Cyber-knife is the latest treatment option for acoustic neuroma. It is totally frameless and more accurate. It uses real-time image guidance technology through computer-controlled robotics.

questions.text: Which of the following branch of the facial nerve is not a subdivision of nervus intermedius?

choices.text: Sensory branches to external acoustic meatus

questions.solution:
The nerve to stapedius is not a subdivision of nervus intermedius.

Nervus intermedius (nerve of Wrisberg) contains sensory fibres of the facial nerve concerned with the perception of taste, parasympathetic (secretomotor) fibres to various glands, and cutaneous innervation. Its subdivisions are as follows

  • Greater superficial petrosal nerve - parasympathetic to the lacrimal gland and mucous membrane of the nasal and oral cavities
  • Chorda tympani - parasympathetic to the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands; taste sensation from anterior two-thirds of the tongue
  • Sensory branches - sensation from part of the tympanic membrane, external acoustic meatus, and skin behind the pinna.

Nerve to stapedius is a motor branch of the facial nerve.

questions.text: A patient presents with loss of taste sensation from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue and hyperacusis. The Schirmer test when performed shows 20 mm wetting of the filter paper strip. What is the site of lesion in the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
The clinical symptoms and Schirmer test interpretation are suggestive of a suprastapedial lesion of the facial nerve.

Injury to nerve to stapedius which is the first motor branch of the facial nerve leads to loss of stapedial reflex and hyperacusis which can be detected by tympanometry.

Injury to chorda tympani leads to loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue which is detected by electrogustometry and reduced submandibular and sublingual salivary flow detected by salivary flow test.

The Schirmer test interpreted as wetting of 20 mm of the filter paper strip is due to normal tear production, hence the greater superficial petrosal nerve is spared.

Normal functioning greater superficial petrosal nerve and injury of nerve to stpaedius and chorda tympani is seen in a suprastapedial lesion of the facial nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a treatment for Frey's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Vidian neurectomy is not a treatment for Frey's syndrome (gustatory sweating). It is a treatment option for crocodile tears (gustatory lacrimation).

Frey’s syndrome (gustatory sweating) 

There are sweating and flushing of skin over the parotid area during mastication. It is a complication of parotid surgery. It results due to aberrant reinnervation of parasympathetic fibres of auriculotemporal nerve (which supplies parotid) with sympathetic sweat glands.

Management options:

  • Use of antiperspirants
  • Subcutaneous injection of purified botulinum toxin
  • Auriculotemporal nerve avulsion 
  • Denervation by tympanic neurectomy

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with right-sided ear discharge, itching and pain for the past 4 days. He gives a history of insect entry into the external auditory canal which he removed himself. On examination, there is purulent discharge in a narrow canal and the tympanic membrane is normal. Which of the following is the most effective single treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of diffuse otitis externa following a trauma. Aural toilet remains the most effective single treatment for this condition.

All exudate and debris should be carefully removed, with special emphasis on the anteroinferior meatal recess, which forms a blind pocket and acts as a reservoir of infective secretion. The aural toilet can be done by dry mopping, suction clearance, or irrigating the canal with warm, sterile normal saline.

Further treatment modalities:

  • After the aural toilet is done, wicks medicated with antibiotic-steroid preparation can be used. These wicks have to be changed daily for 2 to 3 days, which thereafter can be substituted by ear drops.
  • Broad-spectrum systemic antibiotics are used when there is cellulitis and acute tender lymphadenitis.
  • Analgesics are usually a part of management, as otitis externa is associated with severe pain.
  • Gauze wick soaked in 10% ichthammol glycerine is used to reduce swelling.
  • Astringents such as aluminum acetate (8%) or silver nitrate (3%) are used to dry up an oozing meatus.

questions.text: A patient with impacted wax develops a severe cough while performing the following procedure on him. This is due to stimulation of which of the following nerve?
questions.solution:
The image shows syringing which is a procedure done for impacted wax. Reflex cough due to stimulation of the auricular branch of vagus can occur during this procedure.

Wax is made up of sebaceous and ceruminous gland secretions, hair, desquamated epithelial debris, keratin, and dirt. Factors contributing to the accumulation and impaction of excess wax may be a narrow, tortuous external canal, stiff ear, or obstructive lesions in the canal.

Patients with impacted wax may present with impaired hearing, tinnitus or giddiness. Long-standing impacted wax may ulcerate meatal skin and result in the formation of a wax granuloma.

Wax removal is achieved through syringing or other instrumental manipulation. Hard impacted mass may require prior softening with wax solvents in some cases.

The patient is seated, with the ear to be syringed facing the examiner. The patient wears a kidney tray over his or her shoulder and to collect the return fluid, the patient's head is tilted over the tray. A stream of water from the syringe is directed along the posterosuperior wall of the meatus as the pinna is pulled upwards and backward. The ear canal and tympanic membrane must be inspected and dried with a pledget of cotton at the end of the procedure.

Complications of syringing:

  • Vertigo– caloric stimulation of lateral semicircular canal if water is too hot or too cold
  • Rupture of the tympanic membrane
  • Reactivation of quiescent otitis media, if there is pre-existing perforation

Contraindications for syringing:

  • Presence of ear infection, tympanic membrane perforation
  • Presence of grommet or history of ear surgery.

questions.text: A young adult presents with a 3-year history of intermittent ear discharge. He complains of poor hearing, which improves during discharge periods, but is worse when the ear is dry. Which of the following explains this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes the round window-shielding effect that is seen in tubotympanic type of CSOM.

The round window-shielding effect is where the ear discharge shields the round window from sound waves. During the inactive phase (no discharge), the sound strikes both the oval window and round window together and the noise cancels itself out. So, the hearing is worse when the ear is dry.

Cholesteatoma hearer is a patient with a discontinuous ossicular chain but the sound is conducted through the cholesteatoma to the footplate. On removing the cholesteatoma by surgery, the patient has worse hearing.

The term "cholesteatoma" originates from the Greek words "chole" meaning "lipids" and "steatos" meaning "fat." The name reflects the microscopic appearance of the tumor, which may contain a mixture of desquamated skin cells, cholesterol crystals, and other debris that can resemble a pearly substance when examined under a microscope.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presents with features of bilateral conductive hearing loss, not associated with tinnitus. The following image shows the otoscopic findings of her tympanic membranes. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
The otoscopic picture of both the tympanic membranes shows the Schwartze sign. This finding along with the history of bilateral conductive deafness is seen in active otosclerosis.

A reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. 

The tympanic membrane is quite normal and mobile.

Option A: Rising sun sign is seen in glomus tumor.

Option C: Setting sun sign is an eye sign seen in hydrocephalus.

Option D: Cartwheel appearance is seen in acute suppurative otitis media.

questions.text: What are ceruminous glands?
questions.solution:
Ceruminous glands are modified apocrine sweat glands. They open into hair follicles & participate in wax production.

Apocrine glands release their products by decapitation. It is a process by which membrane-bound cytoplasm from the apical surface of the cells buds off into the lumen of the duct and is secreted.

Some apocrine glands have specific names. Those on the eyelids are referred to as Moll’s glands, and those on the external auditory meatus are termed ceruminous glands.

questions.text: Spot the diagnosis based on these clinical findings.
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is Melkerrson-Rosenthal syndrome.

Melkersson- Rosenthal Syndrome is an idiopathic disorder consisting of a triad of

  • Swelling of lips (as in the image on left)
  • Fissured tongue (as in the middle image)
  • Facial paralysis (as in the image on right)

Ramsay-Hunt syndrome: facial paralysis along with vesicular rash in the external auditory canal and pinna due to herpes zoster infection. Hence also called herpes zoster oticus

Moebius syndrome: congenital facial weakness combined with abnormal ocular abduction; one of its presentations is bilateral concurrent facial nerve paralysis.

Guillain-Barre syndrome: It is an acute, frequently severe and fulminant polyradiculopathy that is autoimmune in nature; one of its presentation is bilateral concurrent facial nerve paralysis

questions.text: Which of the following bones does not form the nasal septum?
questions.solution:
The frontal process of the maxilla does not contribute to the formation of the nasal septum. It forms the bony skeleton of the external nose.

Bones forming the nasal septum:

  • Major contribution
    • Vomer
    • Perpendicular plate of the ethmoid bone
  • Minor contribution
    • Nasal bones
    • The nasal spine of the frontal bones
    • Rostrum and crest of the sphenoid
    • Nasal crests of the maxilla and palatine bones

The bony part of the external nose consists of

  • Two nasal bones
  • Frontal process of maxilla lateral to nasal bones on each side.
  • Nasal process of the frontal bone in the midline between 2 nasal bones.
  • Nasion is the site of the junction of nasal bone with the nasal process of the frontal bone.

questions.text: Which of the following paranasal sinus opens into the superior meatus?
questions.solution:
Posterior ethmoidal sinus opens into the superior meatus.

Anterior ethmoidal, frontal, and maxillary sinuses open into the middle meatus.

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: Comment on the given CT image.
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows the concha bullosa, as there are bilateral air-filled middle turbinates.

Concha bullosa is pneumatization of the middle turbinate. Pneumatization leads to an enlarged ballooned out middle turbinate.

The star marked area is the concha bullosa:

Normal CT of the osteomeatal complex

Chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps

CT showing allergic fungal rhinosinusitis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the structure marked with a red arrow?

choices.text: Posterior superior nasal nerves pass through this foramen
It is situated  posterior to the superior turbinate
It is the common site for the origin of an angiofibroma
It serves as a gateway between the pterygopalatine fossa and the nasal cavity

questions.solution:
The structure marked with a red arrow is the sphenopalatine foramen. It is situated at the posterior end of the middle turbinate.

The sphenopalatine foramen serves as a gateway between the pterygopalatine fossa and the nasal cavity. It transmits the following structures from the pterygopalatine fossa to the nasal cavity

  • Sphenopalatine artery
  • Nasopalatine nerve
  • Posterior superior nasal nerves (lateral and medial)

As it transmits the sphenopalatine artery, it is the common site of the origin of the nasal angiofibroma.

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: Which of the following condition is also known as an olfactory hallucination?
questions.solution:
Phantosmia is also known as olfactory hallucination. It is a dysosmic sensation perceived in the absence of an odour stimulus. 

Olfactory disorder classification:

Anosmia: the absence of smell function

Partial anosmia: an ability to perceive some, but all not odours

Hyposmia or microsmia: decreased sensitivity to odours

Hyperosmia: increased sensitivity to common odours

Dysosmia (cacosmia or parosmia): distorted or perverted smell perception to odour stimulation

Olfactory agnosia: inability to recognize an odour sensation

Heterosmia: all the odours are the same

Presbyosmia: a decline in smell sense with age

Osmophobia: dislike or fear of certain smells

questions.text: Which of the following arteries are the branches of the maxillary artery?
questions.solution:
Structure marked B is the sphenopalatine artery and C is the greater palatine artery. They are the branches of the third part of the maxillary artery.

Other structures marked:

A - Anterior ethmoidal artery, a branch of the ophthalmic artery

D – Superior labial artery, a branch of the facial artery

Related Pearl: Divisions of Maxillary Artery and Its Branches

1st part/Mandibular part: 

  • Extend - Neck of the mandible to lower border of Lateral pterygoid
  • Common Pattern - All branches from this part enter the bone.
  • Branches
    • middle meningeal,
    • accessory meningeal,
    • inferior alveolar,
    • deep auricular 
    • anterior tympanic arteries.

2nd part/Pterygoid part:

  • Location - In the infratemporal fossa
  • Common Pattern - All are muscular branches.
  • Branches
    • Artery to lateral pterygoid,
    • medial pterygoid,
    • Masseteric artery
    • 2 deep temporal arteries.

3rd part/Pterygopalatine part:

  • Location - pterygopalatine fossa
  • Branches
    • Artery of pterygoid canal,
    • Infra-orbital artery,
    • Greater palatine,
    • Sphenopalatine artery,
    • pharyngeal artery,
    • posterior superior alveolar artery.

questions.text: TESPAL is__________

choices.text: Ligation of artery by Caldwell-Luc operation

questions.solution:
Transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL), is performed by using rigid nasal endoscopes.

  • Sphenopalatine artery ligation gives high success in the control of refractory posterior bleed. The artery is ligated at sphenopalatine foramen situated 1 cm behind the posterior end of the middle turbinate.

questions.text: The deformity depicted here is:
questions.solution:
In the given image, there is hump (or bump) in the dorsum of the nose, hence the deformity depicted is a hump nose.

The hump may involve the bone or cartilage or both bone and cartilage. This is corrected by a reduction rhinoplasty.

Option B: Deviated nose - Midline is straight but deviated to one side.

 

Option C: In crooked nose, the midline of the dorsum of the nose from the frontonasal angle to the tip is curved in a C- or S-shaped manner. 

Option D: Saddle nose is depressed nasal dorsum.

questions.text: In a patient with findings as shown in the image, which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: It is known as elephantiasis of the nose
It is seen in long standing cases of acne rosacea
It is commonly seen in middle aged women
It is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous glands

questions.solution:
The given image is diagnostic of rhinophyma. It is commonly seen in men past middle age.

Rhinophyma or potato tumour or elephantiasis of nose is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous glands. It is usually associated with long-standing cases of acne rosacea. Mostly seen at the tip of the nose and causes unsightly appearance and obstruction to breathing and vision. 

Treatment: Debulk of the tumor with carbon dioxide laser and the area is allowed to re-epithelialize. Sometimes the tumor is completely excised and skin is grafted over the raw area.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with complete obstruction of his left nostril and a nodule on the dorsum of his nose obscuring his vision as shown in the image. He gives a typical history of foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crust formation even before this nodule developed. The histology of the biopsied specimen is given as an image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of a nodule on the nose and the given histological image showing Mikulicz cells are suggestive of rhinoscleroma.

Mikulicz cells are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli. The history of purulent foul-smelling nasal discharge with crusting before the development of nodules corresponds to the atrophic stage of rhinoscleroma. 

Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus). It has 3 stages:

1. Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul-smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.

2. Granulomatous stage– Painless, non-ulcerative Granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of woody/hebra nose.

3. Cicatricial stage – Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx, larynx. The deformity is called a tapir nose.

Treatment: Streptomycin (1g/day) and tetracycline (2g/day) are given together for a period of 4 to 6 weeks. Steroids can be combined with this to reduce fibrosis. Surgical treatment is necessary to restore the airway and correction of the nasal deformity.

Other options:

Option A: Even though the inner canthus of the eye is a common site for the occurrence of basal cell carcinoma, the given histology does not show palisade of the basaloid epithelium, which is very classical of BCC.

Option B: Rhinophyma or potato tumour is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous gland and presents as swelling over tip of the nose.

Option C: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

questions.text: A man who works in a cattle ranch presented with complaints of a mass protruding from the left nostril and blood-stained nasal discharge. The mass is pink, leafy, and polypoidal and is attached to the nasal septum. Biopsy from the lesion showed several sporangia. What is the treatment of choice for the above condition?
questions.solution:
Surgical management (excision of the lesion with cauterisation of the base), is always the treatment of choice in rhinosporidiosis.

No drug treatment has proved effective, although dapsone is tried in some cases. Followup of the patient after surgical management is necessary, as recurrence is common.

questions.text: An adolescent girl with atrophic rhinitis is using kemicetine antiozaena solution. Which of the following is not a component of this solution?
questions.solution:
Sodium bicarbonate is not a component of kemicetine antiozaena solution. It is used in alkaline nasal solution.

The components of kemicetine antiozaena solution are:

  • Chloramphenicol
  • Oestradiol
  • Vitamin D2. 

It is used in the medical management of atrophic rhinitis.

questions.text: Which of the following types of rhinitis is seen in people who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings?
questions.solution:
Rhinitis sicca is seen in people who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings.

Rhinitis sicca is a crust-forming disease seen in people who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings, e.g. bakers and iron- and goldsmiths. It usually affects the anterior third of the nose, particularly the nasal septum. The ciliated columnar epithelium undergoes squamous metaplasia, along with atrophy of the seromucinous glands. The affected areas develop crusts, which may result in bleeding, ulceration, and even septal perforation on removal.

Treatment consists of correction of the occupational surroundings and application of bland ointment to the affected part. Ointments with antibiotics and steroids can also be used.

Other options:

Option A: Rhinitis caseosa is a condition in which the nose is filled with purulent discharge/cheesy material. It is a unilateral condition mostly affecting males. This condition usually results from chronic sinusitis, where the mucosa of the sinuses becomes granulomatous and the sinuses are filled with cheesy material. Management includes the removal of debris and ensuring good drainage of the sinuses.

Option C: Secondary atrophic rhinitis is a condition when atrophic changes in the nasal cavity occur secondary to specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy, and rhinoscleroma.

Option D: Hypertrophic rhinitis is a condition characterized by the thickening of mucosa, submucosa, seromucinous glands, periosteum, and bone. It occurs as a result of recurrent nasal infections, chronic sinusitis, and chronic irritation of the nasal mucosa. Symptoms include nasal obstruction, discharge, and headache.

questions.text: Which of the following ocular sign seen in allergic rhinitis is called allergic shiners?
questions.solution:
The dark circles seen under the eyes are called allergic shiners.

Congestion and cobblestone appearance of the conjunctiva, Oedema of the lids are the other ocular signs seen in allergic rhinitis.

A finding similar to allergic shiners called allergic salute is seen as a black line across the middle of the dorsum of the nose due to constant upward rubbing of the nose, simulating a salute.

questions.text: The test shown in the image is used to detect the abnormality of_____________.
questions.solution:
The test shown in the image is the Cottle test. It is used to detect abnormalities of the vestibular component of the nasal valve.

In this test, the cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve. The nasal airway improves as the nasal valve opens upon performing this maneuver. This helps us in finding the site of obstruction.

The nasal valve area is the narrowest portion of the nasal passage. It is bounded medially by the nasal septum, superiorly and laterally by the caudal margin of the upper lateral cartilage, and inferiorly by the floor of the piriform aperture; the nasal valve is the specific slit-like segment between the caudal margin of the upper lateral cartilage and the septum.

Conditions with a positive Cottle test:

  • Deviated nasal septum
  • Collapsed nasal valve - causes snoring and sleep apnea
  • Valve stenosis

The following illustration shows the nasal valve and the nasal valve area:

questions.text: In septoplasty, an incision made close and caudal to the caudal end of the septum on one side is called__________
questions.solution:
In septoplasty, an incision made close and caudal to the caudal end of the septum on one side is called hemitransfixion incision.

Other incisions for septoplasty:

Transfixion incision: It is a through and through incision (on both sides), made close and caudal to the caudal end of the septum.

Killian’s incision: It is a curvilinear incision, made 2–3 mm above the caudal end of septal cartilage on the concave side in the nasal mucosa.

A horizontal incision is made on the spur for endoscopic spurectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Samter's triad?
questions.solution:
Allergic rhinitis is not a component of the Samter's triad.

Samter’s triad is associated with aetiology of the ethmoidal polyp. It consists of

  • Nasal polyposis
  • Asthma
  • Aspirin intolerance

Other etiological factors of ethmoidal polyp:

  • Chronic rhinosinusitis especially NARES (non-allergic rhinitis with eosinophilia syndrome).
    Asthma
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Allergic fungal sinusitis
  • Kartagener syndrome- This consists of bronchiectasis, sinusitis, situs inversus and ciliary dyskinesia.
  • Young syndrome- It consists of sinopulmonary disease and azoospermia.
  • Churg–Strauss syndrome- Consists of asthma, fever, eosinophilia, vasculitis and granuloma.
  • Nasal mastocytosis

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with recurrent respiratory infections. After a series of investigations, the boy was diagnosed with Kartagener syndrome. What are the components of this syndrome?

choices.text: Chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis and situs inversus

questions.solution:
The components of Kartagener syndrome are chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus. 

Primary ciliary dyskinesia (also called immotile cilia syndrome) is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting ciliary motility. When a patient has bronchiectasis, chronic sinusitis, and situs inversus triad, he is known to have Kartagener syndrome. It occurs due to the absence of protein dynein in the A tubules of the respiratory mucosa.

The below chest X-ray shows dextrocardia (situs inversus) in Kartagener syndrome.

The disease is usually diagnosed based on the clinical picture and should be evaluated in later stages when a child presents with recurrent lower and upper respiratory tract infections. Other features of primary ciliary dyskinesia include congenital heart diseases and neonatal hydrocephalus. Male patients with this condition tend to be infertile, due to asthenospermia (immotile spermatozoa due to impaired sperm flagella function).  

Transmission electron microscopy is the gold standard investigation to analyze cilia. There is no specific treatment for this condition and is managed according to the symptoms. 

Option A: Asthma fever and eosinophilia are seen in Churg Strauss syndrome. 

Option C: Chronic rhinitis with polyp is seen in chronic rhinosinusitis. 

Option D: Infertility (azoospermia) and bronchiectasis are seen in Young syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following forceps is used to reduce a fracture of the nasal septum?
questions.solution:
Asch's forceps is used to reduce a fracture of the nasal septum.

Walsham and Asch’s forceps are used to reduce nasal bone fractures.

  • Walsham is mainly used to reduce the bone fracture.
  • Asch forceps is mainly used to reduce nasal septum.

Tilly's forceps is used for insertion or removal of nasal packing or dressings.

Citelli's forceps is used for punching bones and other tissues

questions.text: You are an ENT resident evaluating a patient with a fracture of the zygoma. Which of the following findings would you not expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
CSF rhinorrhea is not seen in patients with fractures of the zygoma.

It has the following clinical features:

  • Flattening of malar prominence.
  • Step deformity of infraorbital margin.
  • Anesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve.
  • Trismus, due to depression of zygoma on the underlying coronoid process.
  • Oblique palpebral fissure, due to the displacement of lateral palpebral ligament.
  • Restricted ocular movements, due to entrapment of inferior rectus muscle. It may cause diplopia.
  • Periorbital emphysema, due to escape of air from the maxillary sinus on nose blowing.

The following x-ray shows a right-sided zygoma fracture:

questions.text: Which of the following is false about CSF rhinorrhea?

choices.text: Ethmoid is the most common site of leak
Intrathecal fluorescein study can be used to detect site of leak

questions.solution:
Double ring sign is present in a case of CSF rhinorrhea.

Double ring sign or Halo sign or Target sign - when CSF mixed with blood is collected on a piece of filter paper, it will show a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

Option A: Fracture cribriform plate of ethmoid is the most common cause.

Option B: CSF glucose is 60% of blood glucose.

Option C: Intrathecal fluorescein study is used to detect the site of leak of CSF.

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double ring sign or halo sign or target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

The image below shows the double ring sign in CSF rhinorrhoea:

  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

 

Note: The repeated reappearance of pus immediately after cleaning, in the external auditory canal of patients with acute mastoiditis/coalescent mastoiditis is also referred to as Reservoir sign.

questions.text: A 23-year-old college student presented with jaw pain and trismus after falling from a bike. A diagnosis of mandibular fracture was made. Which of the following classification is used for this?
questions.solution:
Dingman’s classification is used in the classification of fractures of the mandible.

Dingman's classification is based on the region in which the fracture is located. The seven regions used in this classification are as shown below:

Option A: Le-Fort classification is used in maxillary fractures.

Option C: Gartland classification is used in supracondylar fractures of the humerus.

Option D: Pauwell classification is used in the neck of femur fractures.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presented with left-sided nasal blockage and discharge for 3 years. On anterior rhinoscopy, a pale, red polypoidal mass is seen in the left nostril. He was diagnosed with inverted papilloma. Which of the following statements is false about the management of his condition?

choices.text: MRI is the first imaging modality in follow-up

questions.solution:
Radiotherapy is not advised in inverted papilloma since it may induce malignancy.

Option A: Endoscopic approach is preferred to surgical resection.

Option C: There is a high rate of recurrence of inverted papillomas.

Option D: MRI is the first imaging modality to perform during follow up.

Related Pearl: Inverted Papilloma

Inverted papilloma is also known as transitional cell papilloma or Ringertz tumor or Schneiderian papilloma. It is a common benign tumour of the paranasal sinuses. It is a premalignant condition with 10-15% chances of turning malignant.

Etiology: Human papillomavirus has been implicated in its etiology.

Origin: Arises from the lateral wall of the nose from the non-olfactory epithelium of the nose

Clinical features:

  • More common in men.
  • Predominance between 40-70 years.
  • Unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis are the main presenting symptoms
  • It is a locally invasive tumor and can invade orbit and paranasal sinuses.
  • Proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation can result from orbital invasion

Findings: It is seen as a pale polypoidal mass resembling a simple nasal polyp.

Investigations: A biopsy is needed for diagnosis.

Treatment: Medial maxillectomy via lateral rhinotomy or midfacial degloving approach. Radiotherapy can lead to malignancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site for osteomas?
questions.solution:
Osteomas are most commonly seen in the frontal sinus followed by ethmoid and maxillary sinuses.

They remain asymptomatic and are incidentally found on x-rays. Treatment is required only when they cause obstructive symptoms or pressure effects.

The image given shows the x-ray image of an osteoma in the frontal sinus.

questions.text: A 43-year-old factory worker presents to you with nasal obstruction, cheek swelling, and diplopia. The ENT resident suspects maxillary carcinoma and uses the following image to classify the same. Which one of the following classification systems are used?
questions.solution:
Ledermann’s classification is used to classify maxillary carcinoma in this case.

It uses two horizontal lines of Sebileau; one passing through the floors of orbits and the other through floors of antra.

questions.text: A carpenter was diagnosed with sinonasal carcinoma and planned for surgical resection. Which of the following histological varieties would be most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
Adenocarcinoma is the most common variety in this case. Workers of the furniture industry or woodworkers develop adenocarcinoma.

It is most commonly found in the ethmoid sinuses and upper nasal cavity.

Workers engaged in nickel refining may develop squamous cell carcinoma and anaplastic carcinoma.

questions.text: On examining the oral cavity of a patient who presented with fever and a sore throat, you notice a greyish-white membrane over the tonsils. Which of the following conditions would you not consider as a differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ludwig’s angina is not associated with the formation of a grey-white membrane. It is characterized by rapidly spreading infection of the sublingual space initially and later the submaxillary space, often dentogenic in origin.

D/D for membrane over tonsil:

  • Streptococcus & other pyogenic organisms
  • Diphtheria
  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Vincent’s angina
  • Leukemia
  • Candida
  • Agranulocytosis
  • Malignancy
  • Apthous ulcer
  • Traumatic ulcer

questions.text: A middle-aged diabetic man who had undergone a tooth extraction presents with fever and trismus. On examination, his posterior pillar is pushed medially and there is a swelling in the neck at the upper 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of parapharyngeal abscess.

Parapharyngeal abscess presents with:

  • Trismus due to spasm of medial pterygoid
  • Tonsils pushed medially
  • Swelling in the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid (space limited to the level of hyoid bone).

Option A - Retropharyngeal abscess presents as a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall on one side of the midline.

Option C - In Ludwig’s angina, tonsils are not pushed medially.

Option D - Peritonsillar abscess doesn’t produce swelling in the upper 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid.

questions.text: A teenager has a mass in his nasopharynx that has minimally spread into the sphenoid sinus with no lateral extension. Which stage of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma could this be?
questions.solution:
The mass has spread into the sphenoid sinus with no lateral extension, so it's Stage 1B according to the Radkowski classification. 

Multiple classification systems exist for the staging of juvenile nasal angiofibroma, of which the most commonly used ones are the Fisch and Radkowski classification systems: 

Staging of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (Radkowski, et al):

Stage Spread
IA Limited to the nose and/or nasopharyngeal vault
IB Extension into ≥ 1 sinus
IIA Minimal extension into the pterygopalatine fossa
IIB Full occupation of pterygopalatine fossa with or without erosion of orbital bones
IIC Infratemporal fossa with or without cheek or posterior to pterygoid plates
IIIA Erosion of skull base-minimal intracranial
IIIB Erosion of skull base-extensive intracranial with or without cavernous sinus

Fisch staging system of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma:

Type Details
1 Tumour limited to the nasopharyngeal cavity; bone destruction negligible or limited to the sphenopalatine foramen
2 Tumour invading the pterygopalatine fossa or the maxillary, ethmoid, or sphenoid sinus with bone destruction
3 A: Tumour invading the infratemporal fossa or orbital region without intracranial involvement
B: Tumour invading the infratemporal fossa or orbital region with intracranial extradural (parasellar) involvement
4 A: Intracranial intradural tumor without infiltration of the cavernous sinus, pituitary fossa, or optic chiasm
B: Intracranial intradural tumor with infiltration of the cavernous sinus, pituitary fossa, or optic chiasm

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a highly vascular and locally aggressive tumor seen almost exclusively in adolescent males, associated with significant morbidity and occasional mortality. 

Note: The Fisch system is considered to be the more robust and practical of the two.

questions.text: What is the most common presenting feature of nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Painless cervical lymphadenopathy is the most common (60-90%) presenting feature of nasopharyngeal carcinoma followed by- 

  • Hearing loss
  • Nasal obstruction
  • Epistaxis
  • Cranial nerve palsies -Cranial nerves V and VI are the most commonly involved among all the cranial nerves. 
  • Headache
  • Earache
  • Neck pain
  • Weight loss

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is more prone to injury, causing vocal cord paralysis?
questions.solution:
The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is more prone to injury, causing vocal cord paralysis. The reasons being:

  • It is longer as it loops around the arch of the aorta to climb back to the larynx.
  • It is in association with more structures in the mediastinum.

Other options:

  • Right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the subclavian artery and therefore it’s shorter and safer. 
  • Unilateral paralysis of the superior laryngeal nerve is rare and they are usually a part of a combined paralysis.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing a mastoidectomy procedure. During the procedure, a surgeon uses the following instrument to explore the mastoid air cells. Name the given instrument
questions.solution:
The above image is a MacEwen’s curette and cell seeker. During mastoid surgeries, one end is used to explore the air cells and the other end is used to curette the intervening septa and granulations.

Note: MacEwan’s (suprameatal) triangle is an important landmark to locate the mastoid antrum in mastoid surgery. It is bounded by-

  • Temporal line
  • The posterosuperior segment of the bony external auditory canal
  • The line drawn as a tangent to the external canal

questions.text: Which of the following laryngeal carcinomas has maximum lymph node involvement?

choices.text: All have equal chances of lymph node involvement

questions.solution:
Supraglottic carcinoma has the highest chance of lymphatic spread in the larynx. 

Lymph node enlargement is often a presenting complaint as it occurs early in the course of the disease.

questions.text: The X-ray view shown in the image is ____.
questions.solution:
The x-ray view shown in the image is the Caldwell view.

  • The nose and forehead are touching the x-ray film.
  • The x-ray beam is projected 15 degrees caudally.

Structures seen are

  • Frontal sinuses (seen best)
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone
  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

The other options are explained in the pearl given below:

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text: A patient presents with bilateral nasal obstruction. On anterior rhinoscopy, multiple smooth pale glistening masses are found bilaterally suggestive of ethmoidal polyps. The surgeon plans functional endoscopic sinus surgery to remove them. Which of the following structures shown in the image given below is removed during infundibulotomy?
questions.solution:
The image above shows the computed tomography (CT) scan of the ostiomeatal complex in the coronal plane. The structure marked as 1 is the uncinate process which is removed in infundibulotomy.

Infundibulotomy, also known as uncinectomy, is the first surgical step in functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS). FESS is the treatment of choice for ethmoidal polyps, which this patient has.

The structure marked as 2 is the ethmoidal bulla, and is removed in bullectomy.

The structure marked as 3 is the middle turbinate

The structure marked as 4 is the medial wall of the maxillary sinus.

Important steps in FESS:

  1. Uncinectomy or Infundibulotomy
  2. Identification and enlargement of the maxillary ostium
  3. Bullectomy
  4. Penetration of basal lamella and posterior ethmoidal cells
  5. Clearance of frontal recess and frontal sinusotomy
  6. Sphenoidotomy
  7. Nasal packing

Indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis refractory to medical treatment.
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis.
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis.
  • Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball.
  • Antrochoanal polyp.
  • Mucocele of frontoethmoid or sphenoid sinus.
  • Endoscopic septoplasty.
  • Epistaxis control by endoscopic cautery.
  • Foreign body removal from the nose or sinus.

Related Pearl: Ethmoidal polyps

  • Main etiological factor is allergy
  • Usually affects the middle-aged
  • Site of origin: Lateral wall of the nose
  • Clinical features: Nasal stuffiness, headache (due to sinusitis), sneezing, watery nasal discharge, anosmia/ hyposmia, mass protruding from the nasal cavity
  • Findings:
    • Anterior rhinoscopy: Multiple, bilateral polypi that are smooth, glistening, grape-like masses often pale in color
    • They may be sessile or pedunculated, insensitive to probing and do not bleed on touch
  • Investigation of choice: NCCT
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: Which of the following levels includes the jugulodigastric node?
questions.solution:
The jugulodigastric node (JDN) belongs to the upper jugular chain (Level II) lymph nodes.

Lymphatics from the oropharynx drain into the upper jugular chain (Level II), particularly the jugulodigastric (tonsillar) node, which acts as a sentinel node. It is enlarged in both tonsillitis as well as the carcinoma of the base of the tongue.

Level

Lymph node

Ia

Submental

Ib

Submandibular

II

Upper jugular

III

Middle jugular

IV

Lower jugular

V

Posterior triangle

VI

Anterior group

VII

Mediastinal

Virchow's node is located at level VI.

questions.text: Where is Thornwaldt cyst located?
questions.solution:
Thornwaldt cyst is located in the midline of the posterior wall of the nasopharynx in the adenoid mass.

It is an epithelial-lined median recess found within the adenoid mass and extends from pharyngeal mucosa to the periosteum of the basiocciput. It represents the attachment of notochord to the pharyngeal endoderm during embryonic life.

When infected, it may be the cause of persistent postnasal discharge or crusting. Sometimes an abscess can form in the bursa (Thornwaldt’s disease). It is managed surgically by marsupialization of the swelling and complete removal of the lining of the cyst.

questions.text: In which of the following type of tonsillitis, pressure on the anterior pillar causes expression of frank pus or cheesy material from the tonsils?
questions.solution:
The fibroid variety is a type of chronic tonsillitis in which pressure on the anterior pillar causes expression of frank pus or cheesy material from the tonsils. This is regarded as the Irwin Moore sign.

 

Other signs seen in chronic tonsillitis are as follows:

  • They may meet in midline if it is of chronic parenchymatous type
  • Yellowish beads of pus are seen on the surface of tonsils in chronic follicular type
  • Flushing of the anterior pillars compared to the rest of the pharyngeal mucosa 
  • Enlargement of the jugulodigastric lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl complains of low-grade fever and mild discomfort in her throat. On examination, a membrane is seen over the tonsil that can be removed easily. After removal of the membrane, an irregular ulcer is seen on the surface of the tonsil. A smear from the lesion shows a fusiform bacilli and another bacterium. What is the other bacterium?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Vincent's angina. It is caused by the fusiform bacillus and Borrelia vincentii.

Vincent's angina, also known as acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis or trench mouth, is a form of gingivitis characterized by painful, inflamed gingiva with ulcerations of the interdental papillae that bleed easily.

Patients usually present with low-grade fever, halitosis, malaise, lymphadenopathy, sore throat & a membrane over the tonsil. This membrane is easily removed to reveal irregular ulcers over the tonsil.

A throat swab will show both the organisms typical of the disease, namely fusiform bacilli and spirochetes, namely Borrelia vincentii. 

Treatment consists of debridement and oral administration of penicillin plus metronidazole, with clindamycin or doxycycline alone as an alternative.

questions.text: A reactionary haemorrhage after tonsillectomy is due to improper clipping action of which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
A Reactionary haemorrhage after tonsillectomy is due to improper clipping action of the superior constrictor muscle.

The tonsillar artery perforates the superior constrictor and ramifies in the tonsil. Therefore, the presence of a clot can hinder the clipping action of the superior constrictor muscle, resulting in a reactionary haemorrhage. A simple removal of the clot would restore the clipping action of the superior constrictor and arrest the bleeding.

Types of haemorrhages after a tonsillectomy:

Primary haemorrhage - Occurs at the time of operation.
Reactionary haemorrhage - Occurs within a period of 24 hours.
Secondary haemorrhage - Usually seen between the fifth to tenth post-operative days

questions.text: What is the extent of the danger space?

choices.text: Base of skull to tracheal bifurcation
Base of skull to hyoid bone

questions.solution:
The danger space extends from the skull base to the diaphragm.

  • It lies between alar fascia anteriorly and prevertebral fascia posteriorly.
  • It is just posterior to the retropharyngeal space.
  • Infection from this space can spread to the mediastinum, and hence it is named as the danger space.

Extents of the other spaces:

  • Prevertebral space extends from the base of the skull to the coccyx.
  • Retropharyngeal space extends from the base of the skull to the tracheal bifurcation.
  • Parapharyngeal space extends from the base of the skull to the hyoid bone and submandibular gland.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to you with complaints of nasal obstruction and frequent nose bleeds. CT scan shows Holman-Miller sign. You suspect a benign tumour of the nasopharynx. What is its most common site of origin?

choices.text: Anterior wall of the sphenoid bone

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with a CT scan showing the Holman-Miller sign is suggestive of the diagnosis of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). It most commonly arises from the sphenopalatine foramen. 

From here the tumour grows into the:

  • Nasal cavity
  • Nasopharynx
  • Pterygopalatine fossa
  • Pterygomaxillary fossa
  • Infratemporal fossa

Given below is CT showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus- Holman-Miller sign.

questions.text: Which of the following is called cartilage of Wrisberg?
questions.solution:
Cuneiform cartilage is also known as the cartilage of Wrisberg. 

  • It is situated in the aryepiglottic fold in front of the corniculate cartilage on both sides (paired cartilage)

Corniculate cartilage is also known as the cartilage of Santorini.

  • Each corniculate cartilage articulates with the apex of the arytenoid cartilage as if forming its horn. It is also a paired cartilage

questions.text: The key-hole appearance of the glottis seen in phonasthenia is due to the involvement of ______
questions.solution:
Keyhole appearance is seen in phonasthenia when both thyroarytenoid & inter arytenoid muscles are involved.

Phonasthenia is the weakness of voice due to fatigue of the laryngeal muscles.

  • This leads to a phonatory gap.
  • The shape of the gap depends on the muscles involved:
    • Thyroarytenoid alone: elliptical space
    • Interarytenoid alone: triangular space
    • Both thyroarytenoid & inter arytenoid: Keyhole appearance

Spasms of posterior cricoarytenoid muscle cause abductor dysphonia

The image below shows the appearance of glottis in phonoasthenia
